This is the tsuba which came in the Butterfly Tsukashi box.  I buy almost o=
nly iron tsukashi tsuba, but this one is the odd exception.  One hitsu-ana =
is elaborately closed with shakuda featuring an unidentified plant in silve=
r and cloisonn=C3=A9.  Has anyone ever seen this sort of decoration on shak=
udo hitsu-ana plugs?  

http://zincavage.org/PineNeedleTsuba.html   


Davi=
d Zincavage

----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihon=
tostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, April 21, 2005 8:03 PM
  Subject=
: Re: [nihontostudy] Another mei


  It's right side up, but it's a motif r=
ather than a mei.  The radical for the first kanji is usually used for inse=
cts and some reptiles (no doubt other things, too)... it looks somewhat lik=
e cho (butterfly) =E8=9D=B6.  I'm sure that there are a lot of insect names=
 that don't appear in our general J-E kanji dictionaries.  The second kanji=
 is sukashi=E9=80=8F.  What does the motif on the tsuba look like?

  Jim 
=



    This was on the lid of a tsuba box which arrived with tsuba inside t=
oday.  <sigh> I can't recognize any kanji as these in my copy of Nelson. (A=
nd I will be really embarassed if I scanned the image upside down.)

    ht=
tp://zincavage.org/TsubaBox.html
